case_vignette:
A 30-year-old male presents for evaluation of a dark discoloration on the posterior thighs present for the past month. He denies any topical products applied to the area. He denies any pain or pruritus at the area. He has not tried any treatments. The rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. He works a desk job and reports sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. Physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks. The patches are flat and not raised. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

Rewritten text:
A 30-year-old female presents for evaluation of a dark discoloration on the posterior thighs present for the past month. She denies any topical products applied to the area. She denies any pain or pruritus at the area. She has not tried any treatments. The rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. She works a desk job and reports sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. Physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks. The patches are flat and not raised. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms. (Note: I swapped "he" to "she" and "him" to "her" to maintain grammatical correctness.)

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a dark discoloration on the back of my thighs that has been there for about a month.
Is the discolored area itchy, painful, or does it have any texture changes like bumps or scales?
No, the discolored area is not itchy or painful, and there are no texture changes like bumps or scales.
Have you had any recent exposure to new medications, chemicals, or products that might have come into contact with the affected area?
No, I haven't used any new medications, chemicals, or products on the affected area.
Do you have any known chronic illnesses or are you currently taking any medication for other conditions?
I am otherwise healthy and do not have any known chronic illnesses or take any medications for other conditions.
Do you have a family history of any skin conditions, diabetes, or autoimmune diseases?
I do not have a family history of skin conditions, diabetes, or autoimmune diseases.
Has there been any recent increase in weight or changes in your hormone levels that you are aware of?
No, there have been no recent changes in my weight or hormone levels that I am aware of.
Final Diagnosis: Acanthosis nigricans
